title.narrative: Protection and rehabilitation of vulnerable livelihoods of affected population at risk of hunger and malnutrition through agriculture and livestock protection

description.narrative: In line with the HRP 2018 and the 4th reserve allocation strategic priorities, ACF proposes to launch an intervention targeting the most vulnerable drought affected host communities farmers and timely humanitarian response in Feroz Koh, Dawlatyar, and Lal Wa Sarjangal districts of Ghor province. Although natural disasters are seasonal and recurrent, most communities of Ghor province do not have the capacities to cope with and absorb the shocks with no external support. The proposed intervention therefore aims to support the drought affected farmers to cope with the current drought in Ghor province. The proposed intervention will include distribution of agriculture inputs (50 kg of wheat seeds, 50kg Urea and 50kg DAP fertilizers) to 2,500 drought affected households and distribution of livestock inputs (100 kg animal feed, fodder seed and dewormers) to 4,300 households. In addition, sensitization training sessions will be conducted to all the households who received inputs (6,800 at total, please see annex 1 for the detailed number of beneficiaries) aimed at addressing the severe food insecurity in the area. The overall objective and approach envisioned both fits in ACF mission strategy. With the ongoing drought and expected harsh winter due to average precipitation above seasonal norms with high rain and snowfalls forecasted in the country, Ghor will be particularly affected by these harsher climate conditions. Many farmers, including livestock owners are already severely affected in Ghor province and as a result, do not have access to agriculture inputs (improved wheat seeds and fertilizer) and livestock inputs (livestock fodder and fast growing animal fodder seeds) during the winter and upcoming agriculture cultivation season. The farmers and livestock owners are at risk of losing their livestock during the coming winter, in addition to losing cultivation due to lack of available improved wheat seed and animal fodder. For maximized impact, the project will sustain the livelihood of drought-affected households through distribution of agriculture and livestock inputs. ACF will also conduct sensitization trainings to both agriculture and livestock farmers to improve the use of inputs and ensure best possible production at the end of project. Community leaders will be actively involved in the process, particularly during the training sessions to support the use of distributed inputs at field level. The proposed intervention specifically targets food insecure drought affected households who lost their production, have decreased livestock production or lost livestock during 2017/2018.
